prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: we propose the molecular line observations toward 44 GHz methanol maser sources. Target sources and the line information are listed in the scientific justification section (Table 1, 2). Because molecular outflows and 44 GHz methanol masers have wide spatial distribution with size of arc-min scale, we propose mosaic observations of 2' * 2' region at Band 3. While, to estimate the position of possible driving source and to resolve complex morphology of massive star forming region, we need high angular resolution as possible. Thus, we propose the observations with most extended configuration with the highest spatial resolution of 0.5" at 86 GHz. We set different velocity resolution setting for some lines. For example, identifying infall motions require higher velocity resolutions than outflows, thus we set high-spectra resolution of 0.2 km/s for HCO+, which is well-known infall tracer. Also, the velocity resolution of H13CO+ and CH3OH line is set to 0.4 km/s to resolve narrow line width of those line. For SO, CS, H2CS, HC3N, we set velocity resolution of 0.7 km/s which is enough to resolve typical line widths of massive star forming regions. We estimate the observing time based on flux information of SiO lines at with previous observations. SiO lines were detected with peak intensity of 1.6-3 Jy. To detect weak structures of outflows, we set rms of 15 mJy (signal-to-noise ratio >100) with a velocity resolution of 0.4 km/s. The estimated observing time for each science goal is ~ 1 hour, thus, we expect that the program will need ~5 hours. We include other molecular lines to trace shocked molecular gas and dense regions, such as HCO+, CS, and so on. We expect these lines are easily detected because that they are usually brighter than SiO lines.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose molecular line observations toward 44 GHz methanol maser sources detected with KaVA to investigate the morphology of outflow from MYSOs and to study the physical relationship between star formation phenomena and maser emissions. From late 2012, we have been conducting observations toward 6.7/44 GHz methanol and 22 GHz water maser lines with KaVA (KVN and VERA Array). With short baselines of KVN, we successfully made the images of 44 GHz methanol masers with VLBI for the first time. Further observations to measure proper motions of maser features from various species will clarify the relationship between basic star formation process and maser emissions. To investigate the environments associated with various maser emission, we need high-resolution line data covering large spatial range to observe extended outflows and to resolve the complex morphology of massive star forming regions. Thus, high sensitivity and mosaicing capability of ALMA is essential.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: ALMA and KaVA Survey of MYSOs associated with multiple masers Naoko Matsumoto 2013.1.00701.S
